text: What specifically are you talking about when you say 'flow of my content'? I can think of two interpretations of the top of my head: 1) how your writing flows, ie how it is pulling the reader from sentence to sentence; and 2) how your entire post is constructed, ie how the center argument logically progresses from top to bottom.

elements.text: What specifically are you talking about when you say 'flow of my content'? I can think of two interpretations of the top of my head: 1) how your writing flows, ie how it is pulling the reader from sentence to sentence; and 2) how your entire post is constructed, ie how the center argument logically progresses from top to bottom.

text:
Good clarifying question <@U0161DEFV8R>! Understanding that would certainly help.

If it helps, some of the quickest ways to improve flow are:
1. You should be able to understand the basic gist of an article by reading the H1s
2. H1s should directly support the promise of your titles
3. H2s should directly support the promise of the H1
4. Every H1 should start with a clear sentence about that section covers, and close with a clear sentence recapping the main takeaway
5. Paying attention to the intro/conclusion -- people get lazy here. The intro should just get people hooked, shorter is almost always better. The conclusion should make people feel good about you and like you didn't waste their time.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text:
Hi <@UUVC67604>! I recently had to provide similar training for recruiters who are new to the idea of recruitment marketing, which has a ton of overlap to content marketing. It's just geared at candidates rather than consumers. :slightly_smiling_face:

Like BDMs, these recruiters had very introductory knowledge, so I really had to go back to basics. I would say definitely <https://contentmarketinginstitute.com/|use the free resources from The Content Marketing Institute>, and I've attached the presentation I put together for the team. Slides 4-12 are the most high-level, intro stuff, and the proceeding slides get more detailed talking about building personas and audiences and things. Feel free to PM me if you have any questions!

text:
The short answer: stop waffling and repeating yourself.

The longer answer: outline.
Get the structure and flow of your argument just right using outlining. Bullet points only. No full sentence in sight (that would only distract you into phrasing). When you're ready to write, start with opening and closing, so you'll be clear on where you're starting from and what you're working towards. Then write short, clear, active sentences for each of your bullets. Don't give in to the urge to add more than the bullet requires. Be confident and qualify (add conditions or exceptions to what you're saying) only when necessary for clarity.

That should keep you on track.

Pro tip: Make every sentence leave a question in the reader's mind that's answered by the next sentence.

elements.text:
The short answer: stop waffling and repeating yourself.

The longer answer: outline.
Get the structure and flow of your argument just right using outlining. Bullet points only. No full sentence in sight (that would only distract you into phrasing). When you're ready to write, start with opening and closing, so you'll be clear on where you're starting from and what you're working towards. Then write short, clear, active sentences for each of your bullets. Don't give in to the urge to add more than the bullet requires. Be confident and qualify (add conditions or exceptions to what you're saying) only when necessary for clarity.

That should keep you on track.

Pro tip: Make every sentence leave a question in the reader's mind that's answered by the next sentence.

text: I think part of flow is just practice and editing, making sure one idea runs into another. New idea, new paragraph or section. Transition sentences between ideas/paragraphs/sections are crucial, these take practice as well but come more naturally over time. I definitely agree with outlines -- I outline all my writing first. While arranging the outline you can mess with the sections to make sure the ideas build on one another. I think also, guiding the reader through the article is important, explaining data, quotes, examples and tying them back to your main point. A lot of newer writers will just drop in statements and won't explain them, and it's easy to lose the reader that way. Think of it as a conversation, where the ideas flow naturally from one place to another.

elements.text: I think part of flow is just practice and editing, making sure one idea runs into another. New idea, new paragraph or section. Transition sentences between ideas/paragraphs/sections are crucial, these take practice as well but come more naturally over time. I definitely agree with outlines -- I outline all my writing first. While arranging the outline you can mess with the sections to make sure the ideas build on one another. I think also, guiding the reader through the article is important, explaining data, quotes, examples and tying them back to your main point. A lot of newer writers will just drop in statements and won't explain them, and it's easy to lose the reader that way. Think of it as a conversation, where the ideas flow naturally from one place to another.

text: Oh and couple more technical/prose points: vary the sentence length in your writing. And, read your writing out loud (or have the computer read it to you). This will help identify any awkward or clunky areas

elements.text: Oh and couple more technical/prose points: vary the sentence length in your writing. And, read your writing out loud (or have the computer read it to you). This will help identify any awkward or clunky areas

text:
How does the ROI you receive from participating in large digital conferences compare to their IRL counterparts? I’m referring to the multi-day, multi-speaker events. These events often offer digital “booths” and breakout rooms for speakers and sponsors.

(ROI could mean social media attention, press hits, leads, new contacts …. whatever you most care about in your role!)

text: We've been getting roughly the same number of names, but from fewer accounts (ie event organizers get companies to buy blocks of tickets at discounted rates from the in person event) and with very poor engagement.

text: The virtual booths might as well be a display ad for all the value they provide. We had over 500 people "visit" our virtual booth at a virtual event in May and only about 20 actually engaged in conversation by accepting a chat request.

text:
I’m looking to hire a contractor to help fill in SEO blog post writing needs. What are some things that I should include in an initial description? I already have:
1. Who we are
2. Essential skills for the role
3. Responsibilities
4. How to apply
Since I havent hired a person like this before…do I ask for their rate in their application? Or do I clearly state in the application our budget range per article? Thanks for you help!

elements.text: I’m looking to hire a contractor to help fill in SEO blog post writing needs. What are some things that I should include in an initial description? I already have:
Who we are
Essential skills for the role
Responsibilities
How to apply
Since I havent hired a person like this before…do I ask for their rate in their application? Or do I clearly state in the application our budget range per article? Thanks for you help!

text: I always provide an example post and ask for their rates when working with freelancers/contractors. I've found sharing a budget first can lead down the wrong path

elements.text: I always provide an example post and ask for their rates when working with freelancers/contractors. I've found sharing a budget first can lead down the wrong path

text:
Hey y'all. I've had a few folks ask me for ideas around re-purposing podcast content. I usually present this as a "spectrum" of options:

• One the low effort/low cost end you can have Revv churn out legible transcripts and stick those on the podcast page. Also, social media recaps. 
• In the middle, you have more edited Q&A style posts or cleaned up & re-organized transcripts that read like a narrative.
• On the high cost/high effort end, you can create a longform post, kinda in a slimmed down First Round Review way. 
How do you all think about this? Have you seen/produced any other options?

elements.text: Hey y'all. I've had a few folks ask me for ideas around re-purposing podcast content. I usually present this as a "spectrum" of options:
One the low effort/low cost end you can have Revv churn out legible transcripts and stick those on the podcast page. Also, social media recaps.
In the middle, you have more edited Q&A style posts or cleaned up & re-organized transcripts that read like a narrative.
On the high cost/high effort end, you can create a longform post, kinda in a slimmed down First Round Review way.
How do you all think about this? Have you seen/produced any other options?

text: As a writer, I'm always interested in what the company will supply (tools, direction, outline, personas, style guide...?). It helps me gauge effort, rate, and fit. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: As a writer, I'm always interested in what the company will supply (tools, direction, outline, personas, style guide...?). It helps me gauge effort, rate, and fit.

text: I did some freelance work for Quibb doing this. What we'd do is pull out the most interesting points and write them up. So kind of like a slimmed down, nicely edited transcript. Sometimes messing with the structure a bit so it flowed more like a post than a transcript (where sometimes people will jump around between ideas)

text: I think it comes down to the "Why?" in general and which platform you want to repurpose for. You could for example pick out key messages and turn them into images if you plan to promote the podcast via Instagram or you could write it up the way Jessie described it if you want to try to rank for a specific keyword with a blog article.

text:
I'd like to see what exactly you're looking for in a writer. For example, if you like a particular style of writing, you can mention that. Or, if you want samples for a specific niche/industry, do mention that as well.

It acts as an automatic filter for you to get the right applications.
